subject: Re: [junit] Virtualmock in practice?
msgSnippet: ... I m not big into AOP yet, either. When I have done AOP-based work in Eclipse, I have had to turn off automatic builds, which is a /substantial/ hurdle for
messageBody:
wellman_daniel wrote:

> I've got the need to test some legacy code which uses some hard-coded
> references to other concrete objects, or uses a service
> locator/factory to obtain other business objects. I'm reading J. B.
> Rainsberger's excellent "JUnit Recipes" book and this led me to check
> out mock objects.
>
> I'd like to use mock objects to simulate the behavior of these
> collaborating objects (until I can refactor the design of course!).
> Virtualmock seems like a great tool to do this, and the source
> example in the distribution (iutest/test/functional/SampleTest.java)
> makes sense to me. I've never done this AOP-style of development
> though, so while the code seems to make sense, the logic of how to
> modify my ant script and test process is a mystery to me.

I'm not big into AOP yet, either. When I have done AOP-based work in
Eclipse, I have had to turn off automatic builds, which is a
/substantial/ hurdle for me. I'd like to see a recent article on AOP
with Eclipse with the latest versions of the various tools.

> 1. Is virtualmock still in development? I didn't notice any updates
> for about 10 months on the Sourceforge project, and Googling for info
> on virtualmock returned very little (no mailing list discussions,
> etc.?). The included version of AspectWerkz seems to be out of date
> as well (0.9 included, but now 2.0 is available.)

Where's Chad? Chad? What's up, dude?

<snip />
> 3. Does jMock with CGLib provide the functionality to intercept calls
> to concrete objects instantiated by the object under test? (As
> virtualmock appears to do)

I believe so, and in that case, you should give it a try. I'm just an
old fart who insists everything be an interface, so I don't have much
experience using jMock and CGLib. If there's ever a second edition of
Recipes, I'll include it.

> I really like virtualmock's ability to use your compiler's code
> completion and compile-time method invocation validation, though this
> doesn't have to be my main selling point. If jMock with CGLib can
> provide the same sort of functionality (see my point #3) then I'm
> happy to try it out as well.

I think it's worth a shot.

Take care, and good luck.
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com
Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
